column2:
COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country. To enter Solomon Islands from COVID Free countries (and provided their route to Solomon Islands has not included travel through Medium Risk or High Risk countries) travellers must undertake: One COVID PCR test within 72 hours of expected arrival into Solomon Islands, with the result to be sent with a copy of the Pre-Departure Form to NHEOC_REPAT@moh.gov.sb
• One test during quarantine (on day 6 or 7)
To enter Solomon Islands from Moderate Risk countries, including if travelled through en-route to Solomon Islands, travellers must undertake: One COVID PCR test within 72 hours of expected arrival into Solomon Islands, with the result to be sent with a copy of the Pre-Departure Form to NHEOC_REPAT@moh.gov.sb
• Two tests during quarantine (on day 2 and on day 9 or 10)
To enter Solomon Islands from High Risk countries, including if travelled through en-route to Solomon Islands, travellers must undertake:
Two COVID PCR tests: the first on day 9, 10 or 11 before departure, and the second within 72 hours of expected arrival into Solomon Islands, with the results to be sent with a copy of the Pre-Departure Form to NHEOC_REPAT@moh.gov.sb.
• Three tests during quarantine (on day 2, day 7 and on day 13 or 14)
column3:
Quarantine requirement at government designated site. Quarantine requirements for families travelling with children under 18: All members of families travelling with unvaccinated children under 18 years of age will be required to undertake:
• Families travelling with children from COVID Free countries – 10 days quarantine and 2 COVID tests
• Families travelling with children from Moderate Risk countries – 14 days quarantine and 3 COVID tests
• Families travelling with children from High Risk countries – 21 days quarantine and 4 COVID tests
Non-Solomon Islanders must pay for quarantine and COVID-19 tests in one of the local hotels.
column4: To enter Solomon Islands from High Risk countries (including Restricted countries for eligible fully vaccinated travellers) passengers must undertake three COVID-19 PCR prior to flight departure and negative test results are required.
column5:
Latest News:

International Restrictions:
*Entry to Solomon Islands: All non-Solomon Island citizens must receive prior authorisation from the Solomon Islands Prime Minister’s Office before being granted permission to enter the country.
All travellers to Solomon Islands over the age of 18 must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 with the final dose of the vaccination being at least 4 weeks prior to the proposed travel date. No-one aged over 18 and not fully vaccinated is permitted to enter Solomon Islands.
An electronic copy of both sides of the traveller’s vaccination certificate must be sent to the National Health Emergency Operational Centre (NHEOC) at NHEOC_REPAT@moh.gov.sb before approval for travel can be given. Applications must also be made or supported by a sponsor (for example, an employer) in country.
There is a fee of SBD$2000 per application. This is not payable by diplomats, UN employees and others deemed essential by the Solomon Islands Government.
Solomon Islands designate countries as being ‘COVID Free’, ‘Moderate Risk’ or ‘High Risk’. These designations are under constant review and the Solomon Islands Government has not listed publicly which countries fall into each category. Successful applicants will be informed which of the following sets of measures are applicable in their situation. They will be required to follow the measures applicable for countries they have travelled through en-route to Solomon Islands.
To enter Solomon Islands from COVID Free countries (and provided their route to Solomon Islands has not included travel through Medium Risk or High Risk countries) travellers must undertake:
One COVID PCR test within 72 hours of expected arrival into Solomon Islands, with the result to be sent with a copy of the Pre-Departure Form to NHEOC_REPAT@moh.gov.sb
• One test during quarantine (on day 6 or 7)
• 7 days quarantine in Honiara. Travellers will be discharged on day 7 if both tests are negative. To enter Solomon Islands from Moderate Risk countries, including if travelled through en-route to Solomon Islands, travellers must undertake:
One COVID PCR test within 72 hours of expected arrival into Solomon Islands, with the result to be sent with a copy of the Pre-Departure Form to NHEOC_REPAT@moh.gov.sb
• Two tests during quarantine (on day 2 and on day 9 or 10)
• 10 days quarantine in Honiara. Travellers will be discharged on day 10 if all tests are negative
To enter Solomon Islands from High Risk countries, including if travelled through en-route to Solomon Islands, travellers must undertake:
Two COVID PCR tests: the first on day 9, 10 or 11 before departure, and the second within 72 hours of expected arrival into Solomon Islands, with the results to be sent with a copy of the Pre-Departure Form to NHEOC_REPAT@moh.gov.sb.
• Three tests during quarantine (on day 2, day 7 and on day 13 or 14)
• 14 days quarantine in Honiara. Travellers will be discharged on day 14 if all tests are negative
*Quarantine requirements for families travelling with children under 18: All members of families travelling with unvaccinated children under 18 years of age will be required to undertake:
• Families travelling with children from COVID Free countries – 10 days quarantine and 2 COVID tests
• Families travelling with children from Moderate Risk countries – 14 days quarantine and 3 COVID tests
• Families travelling with children from High Risk countries – 21 days quarantine and 4 COVID tests
You should arrange to take a private test.
Non-Solomon Islanders must pay for quarantine and COVID-19 tests in one of the designated local hotels. Anyone testing positive will be moved to an isolation facility, their quarantine extended, and further COVID-19 tests will be taken.
There is a complete prohibition on yachts or pleasure craft entering Solomon Islands territory by sea. This applies to all ports and islands in the territory. You may not enter Solomon Islands by yacht or pleasure craft. Mariners in distress seeking entry as an emergency safe haven should make all efforts to contact Solomon Islands Authorities well in advance of entering. The penalties for entering Solomon Islands by yacht or pleasure craft without permission include forfeiture of the boat, imprisonment, fine and deportation.
If you are already in Solomon Islands and hold a short term visa for Solomon Islands which is close to expiry, you should contact Solomon Island Immigration to get your visa extended. If you are outside Solomon Islands and have a work permit, visa or exemption, you should contact the Ministry of Commerce and Immigration before beginning the return process; visa conditions may have changed since your visa was issued.
*Demonstrating your COVID-19 status: Although we understand that the proof of COVID recovery and vaccination status is being accepted in practice, the Solomon Islands has not yet officially confirmed this. We therefore recommend that you contact your nearest Solomon Islands embassy for advice on entry requirements. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination.
*Quarantine requirements: Entering the country illegally and/or not observing the mandatory quarantine period could result in a fine of up to SBD$1 million (approx. £100,000) and/or 20 years imprisonment.
*Testing / screening on arrival: All incoming travellers eligible to enter the country must complete a Traveller’s Public Health Declaration card. You must provide full details of your place of stay, travel itinerary and current personal contact details in Solomon Islands for 14 days after your arrival/quarantine in Solomon Islands.
You should comply with any additional screening measures put in place by the authorities. If you need further information about entry requirements, contact the local immigration authorities or the nearest Solomon Islands high commission. You should also check with your airline or travel company for the latest information.

Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in Solomon Islands: Taxis are available at the airport and are functioning normally. Internal flights are operating.
*Accommodation: Hotels are open and social distancing is encouraged but not enforced.
*Public places and services: Hotels, bars, restaurants and shops all open as normal. Nightclubs have recently reopened.
column6: US State Dept. COVID-19 Country Specific Information/ Foreign travel advice, Gov.UK/ Kayak/
